items.title: Fix route prefix pop bug
items.body: `Route.scopedPrefix` wasn't being returned to `original`, so nested groups were getting routed incorrectly.

items.title: Travis.yml cleanup
items.body: Updated travis config according to https://swiftenv.fuller.li/en/latest/integrations/travis-ci.html

items.title: Convert SessionDriver to a conformable protocol
items.body: This moves all of the logic for storing session information into a type that conforms to `SessionDriver`. An application can update the session driver at the start of their application by calling `Session.driver = [YourSessionDriverType]()`. The `Session` class is refactored some to delegate value fetching & updating, and session destruction to the `SessionDriver`. Session identifiers have also been moved over to the `SessionDriver` class so driver writers can decide how best to determine key their sessions.

items.title: Adds API for custom controller routes
items.body: This cleans up ResourceController routing and introduces a simple API for routing to Controller actions: app.add(.Get, "foo", FooController.bar)

items.title: got rid of unnecessary memcpy
items.body: This cleanup the memcpy call when construct sockaddr from sockaddr_in

items.title: Convert some Response properties to var
items.body: This will allow a Middleware to alter the Response types instead of having to create a new one

items.title: Make MemorySessionDriver thread safe
items.body: I also moved the handy lock with closure method from SocketServer into an extension. I wasn't sure where we'd put standard library extensions that weren't "fixes", so I made a new "Utilities" folder.

items.title: Add NSData sequencetype extension, and test case
Lw/branch
items.body:
Addresses the issue of xcode project not being able to build and run tests.

Also addresses:
#110
#111

items.title: Changed String to Swift.String
items.body: This works for me. Can someone confirm/explain why this change is needed?

items.title: Adds tests for the Session class
Moves class scoping variables into internal variables
items.body: After talking on slack we came to the conclusion this would be good to reduce shared state within Vapor for the time being until we can reduce the responsibilities of `Application` as this adds no new public API on it.

items.title: Middleware refactor & remove Session shared state
items.body:
@tannernelson This includes `Application` in the `Middleware` `handle` method, allowing the `SessionMiddleware` to operate on application-level data and configure the session there, instead of it being a shared class variable, as we discussed.

The spacing in the diff seems a bit off; It looks right in Xcode. Not sure what to do about that =\

items.title: libc
items.body: Replaced conditional Glibc imports with libc module

items.title: Config support
items.body:
# Config

JSON-based config with support for cascading config based on the current environment.
## Basic Usage

Config will look for a `Config` directory at the root level of your project, alongside `App` and `Resources`

Your directory structure should look like this:

```
App
Config
   app.json
   logs.json
Public
Resources
```

Each JSON file represents a different group of config.  When querying a value in `app.json` You’ll make a call such as:

``` swift
app.config.get("app.port")?.int
```

If you wanted to access a value in `logs.json`:

``` swift
app.config.get("logs.level")?.int
```

You can also use typesafe convenience getters with a fallback value if the config setting doesn’t exist:

``` swift
app.config.get("app.port", 8080)
```
### Example: Config based server ports

`app.json`

``` json
{
    "port": 8888
}
```

`main.swift`

``` swift
app.start(port: app.config.get("app.port", 8080))
```

When running Vapor now, it should start up on port `8888` instead of `8080`.
## Cascading Environment Config

Config uses folders for each environment, cascading downwards.  When loading files from a `production` folder, config will cascade down to the root so you don’t need to redefine every single setting, you can just override the settings you need.

Your directory structure with an environment folder will look like this:

```
App
Config
   production
      app.json
   app.json
   logs.json
Public
Resources
```
### Example: Config based server ports, Redux

While port `8888` may be ideal during develoment with Vapor, in production you’re probably going to want to run on port `80`.

This is simple enough to do with config:

`app.json`

``` json
{
    "port": 8888,
    "title": "My Awesome Vapor App"
}
```

`production/app.json`

``` json
{
    "port": 80
}
```

Using the same code from the previous example:

`main.swift`

``` swift
app.start(port: app.config.get("app.port", 8080))
```

Your app will still run on `8888` locally, but now when you run it in production, it’ll switch to run on `80`.

Since config cascades, you can still query for the `title` config option without having to redefine it in `production/app.json`:

``` swift
Log.info("App title: \(app.config.get("app.title")?.string)") // Will output the same both locally and in production.
```
## Sensitive information & .env.json

Config supports a special type of config file, `.env.json`.  This is where sensitive information such as database passwords should go.  The `.env.json` file should never be committed to version control; instead you should have a `.env.json` file locally for your development environment, and then during your deploy process inject a version of `.env.json` with values matching your production environment.

Unlike other config files `.env.json` is processed differently to allow you to define top level groups within it.  Where other config files have a one to one relationship with their file to a config group, `.env.json` contains multiple groups. If you have `"app": { "key": "value"}` in your `.env.json` file, you’re overriding `key` in the `app.json` file and not creating a new `env` config group.
### Example: Databases Passwords and Encryption Keys

Assuming the following directory structure:

```
Config
   encryption.json
   database.json
```

While it’s perfectly safe to store non-sensitive config values in `encryption.json` and `database.json`, when it comes to credentials and passwords, you probably don’t want those living in version control.

`encryption.json`

``` json
{
   "key": null,
   "cipher": "AES-256-CBC"
}
```

`database.json`

``` json
{
   "database": "my-app",
   "driver": "mysql",
   "username": null,
   "password": null
}
```

With a basic schema now defined for these groups, you can create `Config/.env.json` and fill out the sensitive values:

`.env.json`

``` json
{
   "encryption": {
      "key": "my-super-seret-key"
   },
   "database": {
      "username": "my-user",
      "password": "my-secret-password"
   }
}
```

These values will now override the null values originally defined when being queried in your app.

items.title: Lw/jeeves
items.body:
Starting some of the server transition. This will need a thorough review from multiple parties particularly familiar with sockets to ensure all conditions are being handled appropriately.
- Hummingbird import wasn't working and is temporarily included in the project

items.title: Formalize IP Override
items.body:
The `--ip=` cli option was previously hacked into `Server/Socket.swift`, but now that we're expanding with different server drivers, rather than continuing to have each driver implement on it’s own (see: https://github.com/qutheory/vapor-curassow-server/pull/1), I think it's time to formalize the option.

I've added it throughout Application, ServerDriver and the existing SocketServer.

items.title: swift 3 support
items.body: The RequestFormExtensions file is still causing trouble, but that will be deleted soon.

items.title: type safe routing
items.body:
## Type Safe Routing

Making the following syntax possible:

``` swift
app.get("users", Int) { request, id in
    return try Json([
        "message": "You requested user id \(id)"
    ])
}
```

This requires code generation which is now a separate target called `Generator`. When run, it will generate the necessary files (`Application+Generated.swift` right now)

items.title: remove Foundation
items.body: This branch is going to attempt to remove Foundation from Vapor so that we can support Swift 2.2

items.title: controller factories
items.body: moving #124 here.

items.title: session fixes
Swift 2.2 Compatibility
items.body: There are a few `FIXME`s here that need to be handled. But it's working. :)

items.title: Lock Hummingbird with minor version
items.body: I'll be updating Hummingbird/Strand to 1.1 soon, which will be compatible with Swift 2.2 and the 03-16 dev snapshot. By locking on 1.0, Vapor will continue to work under the 03-01 snapshot, and when its ready for 03-16, it can update to 1.1.

items.title: more 2.2 fixes
items.body:
Fixed up Jay and added tags for 2.2 code.

Also fixed a small issue with Config.
